Author: Gawain#7858
Content: like if mining profitability goes up, other miners can enter, and then profitability goes down, so it naturally corrects so profitability/accumulation is minimal, as miners have to sell most coins over time to cover costs which helps distribution

Author: Gawain#7858
Content: personally I love the idea of such commits for doubel spend protection, just trying to get the rest of it down

Author: Gawain#7858
Content: I been thinking about this for so long on how to have kmd level certainty on checkpoints without the whole PoS type deal. and maybe the answer is simulated pow

Author: Gawain#7858
Content: what if instead of determining irreversible commits via a majority consensus of fixed set of "miners", it was determined by anyone in every bitcoin block with the weight measured by amount of bitcoin they burned, and consensus for childchain looks for chain with the largest burn per bitcoin block

Author: Gawain#7858
Content: burn miners can still batch tx to burn together and save on space, they could leave if got too expensive, could join if profitable, they get rewarded on child chain via rewards of that chain so incentives somewhat aligned still. a burn consensus attack would require someone to burn coins for long time until they run out of finite money, just like in pow

Author: Gawain#7858
Content: they can't double spend because the result of each block is set in bitcoin-quality-stone, it's not most accumulated burn, it's most burn per block

Author: Gawain#7858
Content: if bitcoin gets reorg, it would ofc unfinalize those child chain blocks as well and be based on whatever commits end up on new bitcoin chain

Author: Gawain#7858
Content: burn can include both miner fees and burn addresses for total cost which is what matters

Author: Gawain#7858
Content: since checkpoints would then be safe, the in between checkpoint blocks could be produced with even basic proof of stake. if PoS emission <<  PoB emission, and PoB people have real costs so can't just hold onto stake easily, PoS shouldn't influence the real consensus (PoB) and can handle chain propagation between commits.

Content: yeah, it's not an ideal flexible burn. main problem for me is stake determines who is notary, notaries get paid in stake, notaries have (almost) no reason to sell stake so over time influence grows, and notaries are pretty important since they can invalidate PoW miners on childchain by only notarizing blocks they mine very cheaply.

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: Notaries can‚Äôt invalidate PoW miners

Author: Gawain#7858

Author: Gawain#7858

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: The are just nodes on the network,  don‚Äôt think a couple cpu cores will do anything to preferentially mine blocks on 3rd party chains.  I‚Äôm a notary node. Regenerating fees > burning fees.   Because Math. To fully lock down open notary spots every year an entity or consortium would need 60 million or so KMD,  and notaries have costs and spend much time on doing work for the system they deserve to be rewarded and with a maximum reward of 25-30k  Komodo a year per notary before server costs ,  notaries account for only for 30% ish of the coin generation a year most is done through the reward mechanism.   Notaries have no part in 3rd party block production, only in KMD block production.

Author: Gawain#7858
Content: I agree with that, but it's not about deserve but about decentralization of control. if notaries can pick which fork between commits is real one, they can pick where their rasberry pi can mine all the blocks eventually, so they would get all the rewards, as opposed to much of the rewards, and thus be very hard to fire over time even faster. they can't double spend, but they could for example censor their chain and child chain, front run, and so on, all for little to no cost other than bitcoin fees. if those fees were higher, then they would eventually run out of money and someone else would easily take over, stake excludes people without stake, but PoW and PoB are permissionless so anyone can compete and money runs out.

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: Notaries don‚Äôt pick

Author: Gawain#7858
Content: i just think it's a little backwards. for decentralization you need permissionlessness at base layer and avoiding mechanisms centralizing control over time. bitcoin has that through permissionless PoW and high sunk costs. then you have notaries who are permissioned. and then you have on chain PoW which depends on notaries giving them permission. if you flip last two, you have permissionless bitcoin, permissionless notaries (PoB), and then the less important blocks which can be chosen by permissionless notaries. it's really not a big difference from current system to implement, but security & sustaining decentralization much better.

Author: Gawain#7858
Content: like a central party or a self-appointed federation might also not want to attack necessarily, but issue is you want unlimited independent parties in control so issue is with a fixed number and how stake funds being elected which funds more stake over time.  I think checkpointing to btc has HUGE potential for sidechains, better than merge mining imo

Author: Gawain#7858
Content: if something like kmd implemented eos/evm type flexibility, used bitcoin security, and didn't depend on fixed reinforcing set, I'd be in heaven
